body:
hey @tj ðŸŽ‰ 

hmm, right you can do it with ~~some~~ a lot of hacking:

```
goreleaser --release-notes <(git log --pretty=oneline --abbrev-commit $(git describe --tags --abbrev=0 $(git describe --tags --abbrev=0)^)..$(git describe --tags --abbrev=0) | sort | grep -v docs)
```

I agree that this is not ideal though. The entire changelog is kind of crappy and very basic right now... I'm thinking about improving it by adding PRs merged, issues closed, contributors and that kind of fluffy stuff... For sure personalization would be in mind for all that =D

I was thinking about doing something like this:

```
changelog: # new pipe yay
  sort:
    by: title / commit / none
    direction: asc / desc
  filter:
    include:
      - word1
    exclude:
      - word2
```

This would cover your current request, and we may continue adding new features later.

What do you think?

hmm yea I wonder where to draw the line, having some things baked in would be convenient. I'd be happy with even just being able to specify --release-notes in the config, then we can chuck that one-liner in there or maybe I'll write a little Go program to organize it a bit
Actually --release-notes is probably fine! Feel free to close if no one else wants it, I'll use your snippet and work from there :D thanks!

Nice!

FWIW I think hugo has some custom scripts as well, you can check the source or maybe ping <at>bep :P 

I'll leave the issue here for now... will think more about it later :)

I like the current approach via `--release-notes`. 
By dealing with plain files you are flexible to do unixy things as @caarlos0 showed above, which would be more difficult with a setting in the configuration file.
If we would add changelog options to GoReleaser, it would be hard to decide what should be added and what should be skipped.
I guess in many cases users also like to have a completely custom changelog.

Maybe we can add some examples for different formats to the documentation in the README.
We can start by adding the example from above and later on we can add more examples commands to generate the changelog.

I'm not sure about this, but when running on Travis for only tags, couldn't the above Git command be written as
`git log --pretty=oneline --abbrev-commit $(git describe --tags --abbrev=0)^..`?

The whole thing would be:
```
goreleaser --release-notes <(git log --pretty=oneline --abbrev-commit $(git describe --tags --abbrev=0)^.. | sort | grep -v docs)
```

> I'm not sure about this, but when running on Travis for only tags, couldn't the above Git command be written as
> git log --pretty=oneline --abbrev-commit $(git describe --tags --abbrev=0)^..HEAD?

probably yes...

issue.title: docs: Add example for --release-notes flag (#284)

labels.name: docs
labels.description: A problem or enhancement in documentation

milestone.title: v1.0.0
milestone.description: Intended to be the first stable solution, with most of the features implemented.

issue.body:
I added an example to the docs of the `--release-notes` flag to make the usage more clear (see https://github.com/goreleaser/goreleaser/issues/284).
The example is an realistic use case and might help others to generate their own changelog.

issue.title: docs: Add example for --release-notes flag
issue.body:
I added an example to the docs of the `--release-notes` flag to make the usage more clear (see #284).
The example is an realistic use case and might help others to generate their own changelog.

issue.title: Changelog: Ignore merge commits by default

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

issue.body:
I think the changelog would look better if we ignore the `Merge pull request ...` commits by default.
I am not sure if we should make this the default for everyone or if we should simply adopt the script we use for GoReleaser itself.
Changing the default for everyone might also be good since the majority of projects use Github to merge pull request.
What are your thoughts on this?

body:
@jorinvo I agree, but I also think that most what people want to do is remove commits that match some regexp.

I'll try to hack something for this so we can ask around how people like it or not =)

hey ho folks, check out https://github.com/goreleaser/goreleaser/pull/401 :D

cc/ @tj @jorinvo
